results.abstract: Ken Kesey, author of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, attends performance of its Broadway adaptation and signs paperback copy of novel for Gary Sinise, play's star; says he admires this production but his favorite is one he saw 15 years ago in Sacramento high school; photos (M)

headline.main: Ken Kesey, Checking In on His Famous Nest

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST (PLAY)

results.snippet: At 65, Ken Kesey no longer cruises around in a multicolored school bus with his band of Merry Pranksters. But standing backstage at the Royale Theater after the Steppenwolf Theater Company's performance of the play based on his 1962 novel, ''One Flew...
results.lead_paragraph: At 65, Ken Kesey no longer cruises around in a multicolored school bus with his band of Merry Pranksters. But standing backstage at the Royale Theater after the Steppenwolf Theater Company's performance of the play based on his 1962 novel, ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' he made it clear that he has not entirely abandoned his prankster ways. ''You did a great performance,'' he told the play's star, Gary Sinise, ''but not quite as good as the one where you were going into space -- 'Apollo 13,' '' the 1995 film in which Mr. Sinise played an astronaut. Mr. Sinise, recovering from his all-out three-hour performance with a mug of tea, smiled politely and held out a faded paperback copy of the novel for Mr. Kesey to autograph. Mr. Kesey added that he had long suspected that Mr. Sinise was the illegitimate son of the actor DeForest Kelley, who played the doctor on the television show ''Star Trek,'' because of their physical resemblance.

results.abstract: Roundup of upcoming summer films; photos (M)

headline.main: Locations, Locations: Around the World in 90 Days

results.snippet: LOVE is everywhere, and we mean that geographically: New York, California, Montana, Cape Cod, fin de siècle Paris, début de siècle Appalachia, China, Ireland, Iceland, rural Sweden and, of course, cyberspace. As the summer movie season gets under...
results.lead_paragraph: LOVE is everywhere, and we mean that geographically: New York, California, Montana, Cape Cod, fin de siècle Paris, début de siècle Appalachia, China, Ireland, Iceland, rural Sweden and, of course, cyberspace. As the summer movie season gets under way -- long before summer itself -- expect the usual number of gangsters, heists, talking animals (well, at least three casts full) and adolescents coming of age. But this year they seem so global. Even World War II will be seen from at least four vantage points (Hawaii, Greece, France and Czechoslovakia). The only thing going in more directions is science fiction, which this season comes in comic, romantic, athletic and Japanese noir varieties, with androids, apes, dinosaurs and computer-generated actors, who don't come from anywhere. Opening dates are subject to change. May SHREK -- DreamWorks's latest animated feature, about an ugly green Scottish ogre sent to fetch a beautiful but geographically undesirable princess. Yes, the ridiculous Lord Farquaad's kingdom does look a lot like a certain amusement park in Anaheim. With the voices of Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz, John Lithgow and Eddie Murphy (as a donkey who won't shut up). Opens Wednesday. A related article is on page 4. AMY -- When a rock star dies tragically, his daughter is so traumatized that she stops speaking. Rachel Griffiths and Alana De Roma star in a drama about communicating through music. Directed by Nadia Tass. Friday. ANGEL EYES -- Luis Mandoki directed this drama about a Chicago policewoman (Jennifer Lopez) in love with a lost soul (Jim Caviezel, who played Dennis Quaid's son in ''Frequency''). Friday. FAST FOOD, FAST WOMEN -- In New York even romantic comedy is hard. A coffee shop waitress accepts a blind date, her favorite customer responds to a lonely hearts ad, then random chance steps in. With Louise Lasser, Anna Thomson, Robert Modica and Jamie Harris (Richard's other son). Directed by Amos Kollek. Friday. MOULIN ROUGE -- Montmartre in 1899 with 20th-century pop music. Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor star as a singer-courtesan and the writer who wants to save her from decadence. A musical directed by Baz Luhrmann, who did ''Romeo and Juliet'' set in Florida. Friday. PETITS FRÈRES -- From Jacques Doillon (''Ponette''), what may be France's answer to ''Kids.'' A drama about adolescents from gritty Parisian suburbs, focusing on a runaway girl, her dog and the boys who try to sell it. Friday. STRANGE FITS OF PASSION -- A young Australian woman (Michela Noonan) sets out to lose her virginity. Mitchell Butel plays her gay best friend. A comic drama directed by Elise McCredie. Friday. OUR SONG -- Coming of age in Crown Heights. A drama from Jim McKay, who did ''Girls Town,'' starring three newcomers -- Kerry Washington, Melissa Martinez and Anna Simpson -- and the Jackie Robinson Steppers. It won two awards at Sundance and glowing reviews at the New Directors/New Films series. May 23. THE MAN WHO CRIED -- Love versus escape in Paris on the eve of World War II. Cate Blanchett, Christina Ricci, Johnny Depp (playing a Gypsy again) and John Turturro in a romantic drama written and directed by Sally Potter, who did ''Orlando.'' May 25. PEARL HARBOR -- The most anticipated film of the season. Ben Affleck, Josh Hartnett and Kate Beckinsale in a drama about two pilots, a Navy nurse and the effect the Japanese attack on Hawaii on Dec. 7, 1941, has on their lives. They say the bombing scenes are unforgettable. Written by Randall Wallace (''Braveheart'') and directed by Michael Bay (''Armageddon''). May 25. THE ROAD HOME -- From Zhang Yimou, who did ''Raise the Red Lantern.'' It's a drama about first love in pre-Cultural Revolution China, staring Zhang Ziyi, the young actress who played the willful governor's daughter Jen Yu in ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.'' This film won prizes at both the Sundance and Berlin film festivals. May 25. THE LONG RUN -- He tried and failed to win the Comrades ultramarathon in South Africa. Now he's a coach with his eye on a talented young runner, so he'll live through her. Armin Mueller-Stahl and Nthati Moshesh star. Jean Stewart directed. May. June THE ANIMAL -- From the people who gave us ''Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo.'' A comedy about a lowly file clerk (Rob Schneider) who has a trans-species transplant and becomes a supercop. Directed by Luke Greenfield. June 1. BREAD AND ROSES -- From Ken Loach, a sort of Latina ''Norma Rae.'' A young Mexican woman (Pilar Padilla), working as a cleaning woman in Los Angeles, meets a young union organizer (Adrien Brody). June 1. EVERYTHING MOVES ALONE -- A dark comedy about a suicidal soldier. From a team of beginning filmmakers, who did it all with a budget of $9,000. June 1. A LOVE DIVIDED -- She's Protestant, he's Catholic, and she thinks they should get to decide how to rear the children. But it's Ireland in the 1950's. A romantic drama starring Orla Brady and Liam Cunningham. Directed by Sydney Macartney. June 1. A REAL YOUNG GIRL -- A sexually curious French boarding school student who doesn't want to spend the summer with her parents. Catherine Breillat's 1976 drama, having its first American release. Charlotte Alexandra and Hiram Keller star. June 1. WHAT'S THE WORST THAT COULD HAPPEN? -- A ruthless billionaire steals a thief's lucky ring. Martin Lawrence, Danny DeVito and John Leguizamo star in a caper comedy directed by Sam Weisman. June 1. THE WIDE BLUE ROAD -- The American theatrical premiere of Gillo Pontecorvo's 1957 drama about a fisherman (Yves Montand) with unorthodox methods. June 6. THE ANNIVERSARY PARTY -- Alan Cumming and Jennifer Jason Leigh must have hit it off in the stage production of ''Cabaret.'' They wrote, directed and star in this drama about a recently reconciled married couple who invite friends over, then get a little too honest. With Kevin Kline, Phoebe Cates and Gwyneth Paltrow. June 8. A related article is on page 24. ATLANTIS: The Lost Empire -- It's about time some --body made a cartographer the hero. In Disney's latest animated extravaganza, young Milo the museum mapmaker finds a long-lost map and is soon guiding an expedition to find the lost continent of Atlantis. Directed by Kirk Wise and Gary Trousdale, who did ''Beauty and the Beast.'' With the voices of Michael J. Fox, James Garner and Leonard Nimoy, among others. June 8. BRIDE OF THE WIND -- Sarah Wynter (''The Sixth Day'') as Alma Mahler, an ahead-of-her-time composer in turn-of-the-century Vienna with a taste for powerful men. Her husbands are played by Jonathan Pryce (as Gustav Mahler) and Vincent Pérez (as Oskar Kokoschka). Directed by Bruce Beresford (''Driving Miss Daisy''). June 8. DEAD OR ALIVE -- Turf war in Tokyo. A thriller about yakuza gangs, directed by Takashi Miike. June 8. DIVIDED WE FALL (MUSIME SI POMAHAT) -- An Oscar nominee for best foreign language film. From the Czech director Jan Hrebejk, a World War II comic drama about a childless couple hiding a Jewish young man from the Nazis. June 8. EVOLUTION -- David Duchovny plays the Mulder-''X Files'' thing for laughs while Julianne Moore follows up her megafame-maker hit ''Hannibal'' by playing a government scientist. A meteor hits earth, and the next thing you know we've got pterodactyls. Directed by Ivan Reitman, who has accomplished scary comedy before, in ''Ghostbusters.'' June 8. SWORDFISH -- John Travolta as a C.I.A. agent trying to steal $9 billion. With the help of a sexy associate (Halle Berry) and a computer hacker (Hugh Jackman). Directed by Dominic Sena, who did ''Gone in 60 Seconds'' and ''Kalifornia.'' June 8. SEXY BEAST -- Ben Kingsley and Ray Winstone in a comic crime drama about a happily retired ex-con and the criminal trying to talk him into doing one last heist. Mr. Kingsley plays the bad guy. Directed by Jonathan Glazer. June 13. BETTER THAN SEX -- An Australian one night stand turns into something more. The participants are a wildlife photographer (David Wenham) and a dressmaker (Susie Porter). A romantic comedy from a first-time writer and director, Jonathan Teplitzsky. June 15. DIRTY COP, NO DONUT -- What if a show like ''Cops'' followed one foulmouthed, gluttonous, drug-using police officer with an attitude problem? A mock documentary from Tim Ritter. June 15. EVERYBODY FAMOUS! -- Another best foreign film nominee, this one from Belgium. A comedy about a factory worker who kidnaps the country's biggest pop star. Written and directed by Dominique Deruddere. With Josse de Pauw and Werner de Smedt. June 15. RUSSIAN DOLL -- An Australian marriage of convenience warms up. He's a lonely detective. She's his best friend's mistress (and a widowed mail order bride from Russia). With Hugo Weaving (''The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,'' ''The Matrix''), Natalia Novikova and David Wenham. Stavros Kazantzidis directed. June 15. SONGCATCHER -- Janet McTeer as a musicologist who discovers a treasure-trove of folk songs and a handsome mountain man (Aidan Quinn). Set in Appalachia in 1907. Directed by Maggie Greenwald. June 15. TOMB RAIDER -- Angelina Jolie turns action-adventure star as Lara Croft, video game heroine. Ms. Jolie's co-stars include her father, Jon Voight, as her father; and Iain Glen, as the leader of the evil Illuminati, who want to rule the universe. Filmed in England, Iceland and Cambodia. Directed by Simon West (''Con Air''). June 15. A related article is on page 4. THE CRIMSON RIVERS -- Murder in a college town in the French Alps, the desecration of a child's grave in another town. Two policemen (Jean Reno and Vincent Cassel) and two cases collide. A thriller directed by Mathieu Kassovitz. June 22. DR. DOLITTLE 2 -- Eddie Murphy is back, talking to the animals, and they all seem to want sex advice. They're also planning to strike to save their forest. Directed by Steve Carr. June 22. A related article is on page 3. THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS -- A young undercover cop (Paul Walker) infiltrates Los Angeles street racing teams, which are like gangs but not really. An action-adventure film directed by Rob Cohen, who did the guys-together thing with HBO's ''Rat Pack.'' June 22. FOR DA LUV OF MONEY -- A comedy about a regular guy who doesn't know the loot from an armored truck robbery is in his backyard. Written and directed by Pierre, who also stars. June 22. JIN-ROH (THE WOLF BRIGADE) -- One French critic called it Japanese science-fiction film noir. It's also animated and set in a hypothetical Japan that won the war. Directed by Hiroyuki Okiura. June 22. THE PRINCESS AND THE WARRIOR -- Actually, the psychiatric nurse and the small-time crook. From Tom Tykwer, who did ''Run Lola Run,'' a romantic drama about obsession. Franka Potente (who played Lola) and Benno Fürmann star. June 22. A related article is on page 30. W.I.S.O.R. -- All about the very important robot that welds and inspects New York steam pipes for Con Edison. From Michael Negroponte, whose past documentaries include ''Jupiter's Wife.'' June 22. BABY BOY -- John Singleton goes back to the hood of ''Boyz N the Hood'' for this drama about a misguided 20-year-old (Tyrese Gibson) in inner-city L.A. With Omar Gooding and Ving Rhames. June 27. LUMUMBA -- The prime minister of Zaire (the former Belgian Congo), his dream of African independence and his violent death. A political thriller directed by Raoul Peck. Eriq Ebouaney plays the title role; Alex Descas is his enemy, Joseph Mobutu. June 27. A.I. -- A hands-on Steven Spielberg project. He directed this story of an 11-year-old android boy of the future (Haley Joel Osment), one of the first computers to be aware of their own existence. Jude Law also stars. June 29. A related article is on page 11. CUPID'S MISTAKE -- A photographer, two actresses and a body builder in Los Angeles. A romantic comedy from Young Man Kang. June 29. THE CLOSET -- A 40ish Frenchman pretends he's gay so he won't be fired from his job at the condom factory. Daniel Auteuil and Gérard Depardieu are the comic co-stars. Francis Veber directed. June 29. COME UNDONE -- Hot summer nights in a French beach town. This film about first love from Sébastien Lifshitz is being promoted as a gay ''Summer of '42.'' With Jérémie Elkaïm and Stéphane Rideau. June 29. POOTIE TANG -- That suave ladies' man and superhero from ''The Chris Rock Show.'' With Lance Crouther, Andy Richter, Mr. Rock and Robert Vaughn (as the evil cigarette, alcohol and fast food mogul Dick Lecter). Written and directed by Louis CK. June 29. ADVENTURES OF FELIX (DRÕLE DE FÉLIX) -- A gay French road-movie that's also a social comedy. A young North African man (Sami Bouajila) from Dieppe goes in search of the father he has never met. Written and directed by Jacques Martineau and Olivier Ducastel. June. BIG EDEN -- A gay romantic triangle in Montana. A lonely New York artist goes back to his hometown and re-encounters his unrequited high school love. With Arye Gross, Louise Fletcher and Eric Schweig. The first-time director is Thomas Bezucha. This won awards at several gay and lesbian film festivals. June. HIMALAYA -- Dueling yak caravans in Nepal. A drama about man versus nature and an ancient ritual. This was nominated for the best foreign film Oscar under the title ''Caravan.'' The first-time director is Eric Valli, an author and National Geographic photographer. June. July CATS AND DOGS -- While you're at work, your pets are at war. And a cat with the voice of Sean Hayes is scheming to take over the world. Jeff Goldblum and Elizabeth Perkins star in this live-action, animatronic, computer-generated action comedy. Directed by Larry Guterman. July 4. SCARY MOVIE 2 -- Keenen Ivory Wayans directs his brothers Marlon and Shawn, who wrote the script, in the sequel to last summer's gross-out horror spoof. This time they're trapped in a haunted house. And James Woods plays the exorcist. July 4. A related article is on page 3. BAISE-MOI (RAPE ME) -- A hardened prostitute and a young woman who has been raped go on the road and take vengeance on men. Directed by Virginie Despentes and Coralie Trin-Thi. Raffaela Anderson and Karen Bach star. July 6. JUMP TOMORROW -- A romantic comedy cum road movie, heavy on the fantasies of a Nigerian introvert (Tunde Adebimpe) who falls for a Latina (Natalia Verbeke). Shades of ''An Affair to Remember,'' they're both engaged to others. Written and directed by Joel Hopkins. July 6. KISS OF THE DRAGON -- Jet Li in an action thriller set in Paris. He plays an agent accused of murder. Bridget Fonda is an American forced into prostitution. Directed by Chris Nahon. July 6. LOST AND DELIRIOUS -- Three girls coming of age, sexually and otherwise, at boarding school. With Piper Perabo, Jessica Pare and Misha Barton. From the Canadian director Lea Pool. July 6. THE VERTICAL RAY OF THE SUN -- The ''Scent of Green Papaya'' team -- the French-Vietnamese director Tran Anh Hung and his wife, the actress Tran Nu Yen Khe, reunite for a family drama set in present-day Hanoi. Three sisters get together for the anniversaries of their parents' deaths. July 6. ADANGGAMAN -- The slavery experience as seen through one young 17th-century African man's experience. Directed by the Ivory Coast-born Roger Gnoan M'bala. July 11. FINAL FANTASY: THE SPIRITS WITHIN -- Earth people versus space aliens who steal their energy. Computer-generated human characters with the voices of Alec Baldwin, Ving Rhames, Ming-Na and James Woods. Directed by Hironobu Sakaguchi. July 11. A related article is on page 4. BREAD AND TULIPS -- A major box office hit in Italy, where it won nine Davids (Oscar equivalents). An unappreciated housewife and mother on vacation is accidentally left behind in Venice, then decides to stay to make a new life. A romantic farce directed by Silvio Soldini. Licia Maglietta and Bruno Ganz star. July 13. BULLY -- From Larry Clark, who got moviegoers' attention with ''Kids,'' the horrible true-crime story of a 20-year-old's murder in Florida by his own circle of teenage friends. They thought he was too bossy. With Brad Renfro, Nick Stahl and Rachel Miner. July 13. DOWNTOWN 81 -- Jean-Michel Basquiat plays an artist trying to sell a painting for rent money. A day in the life of the art and music scene below Houston Street 20 years ago (when the film was made). Directed by Edo Bertoglio. With 80's bands like Kid Creole and the Coconuts. July 13. GREENFINGERS -- Gardening in prison. Helen Mirren (as the outside expert), Clive Owen and David Kelly in a lighthearted story about friendship, love, seeds, bad soil and the Hampton Court Palace Flower Show. Directed by Joel Hershman. July 13. LE BOSSU (THE HUNCHBACK) -- Murdered duke, royal orphan, protector's revenge. Daniel Auteuil and Vincent Perez in a swashbuckling fairy-tale-style adventure set during Louis XIV's reign. Directed by Philippe de Broca. July 13. LEGALLY BLONDE -- Pollyana as a California sorority girl trying to win back her Ivy League beau. Reese Witherspoon stars as the fish out of water in Cambridge, Mass. With Matt Davis, Selma Blair and Moondoggie the Chihuahua. Directed by Robert Luketic. July 13. MADE -- The men of ''Swingers'' return in a comedy about an aspiring boxer (Jon Favreau) and his best friend, an aspiring mobster (Vince Vaughn). With Peter Falk and Sean whatever-his-rap-name-is Combs. Mr. Favreau wrote and directed. July 13. A related article is on page 24. THE RIVER -- Mom's having an affair. Dad spends all his time at gay saunas. No wonder young Hsiao-Kang ends up in the polluted Tamsui River. From Tsai Ming-Liang, a Taiwanese drama, which won the Silver Bear at the Berlin Film Festival. July 13. THE SCORE -- Wow, even Marlon Brando has a summer film. He stars with Robert De Niro, Nick Nolte and Angela Bassett in a drama about a career thief (Mr. De Niro) who breaks his own cardinal rule: always work alone. Directed by Frank Oz. Without Muppets. July 13. JURASSIC PARK III -- Old island, new dinosaurs, mostly new cast. Seven unlucky people (including Sam Neill, Téa Leoni and William H. Macy) find themselves marooned with scary prehistoric creatures. Because there are still people crazy enough to pay for the thrill of raptor viewing. Directed by Joe Johnston, who did ''Jumanji'' and ''October Sky.'' July 18. A related article is on page 3. AMERICA'S SWEETHEARTS -- Julia Roberts stars, but Catherine Zeta-Jones and John Cusack are the title characters, a movie star and her husband in the middle of a press junket who aren't as happy as they look. Ms. Roberts is the star's sister -- and her personal assistant (we know she can play humble). Billy Crystal is the press agent. Directed by Joe Roth. July 20. A related article is on page 13. CRAZY/BEAUTIFUL -- Kirsten Dunst stars in a high school drama about a rich California girl and a poor boy (Jay Hernandez) in love. Directed by John Stockwell. July 20. HAPPENSTANCE (LE BATTEMENT D'AILES DU PAPILLON) -- A day in Paris for about two dozen total strangers whose random actions have consequences for the others. With Audrey Tautou and the French pop star Faudel. Written and directed by Laurent Firode. July 20. HEDWIG AND THE ANGRY INCH -- How an East German boy named Hansel fell in love with an American soldier, had a botched sex change operation and ended up as an ''internationally ignored'' rock star. John Cameron Mitchell recreates the role that won him rave Off Broadway reviews. He also wrote the screenplay (Stephen Trask wrote the music) and directed. They loved it at Sundance. July 20. A related article is on page 11. UNDER THE SUN -- An illiterate Swedish farmer and his best friend compete for the beautiful new housekeeper. Rolf Lassgard, Johan Widerberg and Helena Bergstrom star. Colin Nutley directed. July 20. 101 REYKJAVIK -- A young Icelandic slacker falls for a Flamenco dancer. Too bad his mother wants her too. A dark comedy from Iceland, written and directed by Baltasar Kormakur. July 25. HIGHER ED -- A comedy about an inner-city guy's introduction to college. Written and directed by Jean-Claude LaMarre. Pras, Aries Spears and Hill Harper star. July 27. JACKPOT -- From Michael and Mark Polish, the creators of ''Twin Falls, Idaho,'' a sure-to-be-quirky road movie about a paunchy, balding guy on a karaoke tour of small western towns. With Jon Gries, Garrett Morris and Daryl Hannah. July 27. PLANET OF THE APES -- Tim Burton reworks the 1968 hit about a world run by talking simians. Mark Wahlberg plays the lost astronaut (the Charlton Heston role). But the producers promise that the planet isn't Earth this time and that the new surprise ending will not involve the Statue of Liberty. With Helena Bonham Carter, Michael Clarke Duncan, Tim Roth and a cameo by Mr. Heston. July 27. A related article is on page 3. BROTHER -- Turf war in Los Angeles. Beat Takeshi as a Japanese gangster new in town who takes over a rival gang without even bothering to learn English. This is Takeshi Kitano's first film made outside Japan. July. CURE -- A strange drifter causes supposedly normal people to commit murders. A psychological thriller from Kiyoshi Kurosawa (no relation to Akira Kurosawa). Koji Yakusho stars. July. STRICTLY SINATRA -- A small-time singer in Glasgow, a cigarette girl and the mob. With Ian Hart and Kelly Macdonald. A romantic drama, written and directed by Peter Capaldi (''Franz Kafka's It's a Wonderful Life''). July. THOMAS IN LOVE -- The joys of agoraphobia in the computer age. A romantic drama about a lonely guy whose therapist signs him up for an online dating service. Benoit Verhaert stars. Pierre-Paul Renders directed. July. August THE DEEP END -- A suspense thriller starring Goran Visnjic (the Croatian heartthrob from ''E.R.'') and Tilda Swinton (''Orlando''). It's about a woman covering up a murder to protect her son. Scott McGehee and David Siegel wrote and directed. Aug. 1. ALL OVER THE GUY -- A romantic comedy about 20-something opposites who attract. With Richard Ruccolo, Lisa Kudrow, Christina Ricci and Dan Bucatinsky (who wrote it). Directed by Julie Davis. Aug. 3. BUBBLE BOY -- Twenty-five years ago it was a poignant drama. Now it's a comedy. Jake Gyllenhaal plays a bacteria-intolerant 21-year-old who designs a mobile bubble so he can stop the wedding of the woman he loves. Swoosie Kurtz plays his overprotective mother. Directed by Blair Hayes. Aug. 3. GHOST WORLD -- Based on the comic book of the same name. A comic drama about two bored, sarcastic recent high school graduates (Thora Birch and Scarlett Johannson) who stalk a lonely man (Steve Buscemi) for fun. Directed by Terry Zwigoff, who did ''Crumb.'' Aug. 3. THE MONKEY'S MASK -- Lesbian noir. A private eye and a poetry professor she meets while investigating a student's disappearance. With Susie Porter and Kelly McGillis. Directed by Samantha Lang. Aug. 3. ORIGINAL SIN -- Angelina Jolie and Antonio Banderas in a thriller about a wealthy Cuban coffee exporter and his mysterious American mail-order bride. Maybe a little too mysterious. Written and directed by Michael Cristofer, who directed Ms. Jolie in HBO's ''Gia.'' Aug. 3. THE PRINCESS DIARIES -- A San Francisco teenager learns she's actually a European royal. But she is not interested in her grandmother's how-to-be-a-princess lessons. A comedy from Garry Marshall, with Anne Hathaway, Julie Andrews and Hector Elizondo. Aug. 3. RAT RACE -- From Jerry Zucker, who gave us ''Airplane!'' and ''Naked Gun,'' an ensemble comedy about a casino tycoon and six people competing for $2 million. With John Cleese, Whoopi Goldberg, Cuba Gooding Jr., Jon Lovitz, Rowan Atkinson, Seth Green and Dean Cain. Aug.3. -- RUSH HOUR 2 -- The first one was a surprise comedy hit, so Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker are back as detective partners chasing a big-time gangster. They're in Hong Kong, Los Angeles and Las Vegas. Brett Ratner returns as director. --Aug. 3. A related article is on page 3. TORTILLA SOUP -- A Mexican-American remake of --Ang Lee's ''Eat Drink Man Woman,'' a romantic comedy about a chef and his three daughters. With Hector Elizondo, Elizabeth Peña and Raquel Welch. Directed by Maria Ripoli. Aug. 3. AUDITION -- A Japanese psychological thriller about a widower who decides to find a new wife by pretending to audition actresses for a film. One woman seeks revenge. Directed by Takashi Miike. Aug. 8. AMERICAN PIE 2 -- A sequel to the teenage-virginity comedy about high school boys and early sexual experiences with desserts. The old cast is back (including Jason Biggs, Shannon Elizabeth and Eugene Levy), and the boys have a year of college behind them. J. B. Rogers is the director. Aug. 10.A related article is on page 3. AN AMERICAN RHAPSODY -- A drama about a little girl left behind in Communist Hungary when her parents (Tony Goldwyn and Nastassja Kinski) escape to the West. Scarlett Johansson plays the girl as a teenager, dealing with major identity issues. Aug. 10. CURSE OF THE JADE SCORPION -- Woody Allen's newest comedy, starring Mr. Allen as an insecure insurance investigator in 1940's New York. With Helen Hunt (continuing her quest to play opposite every leading man alive), Dan Aykroyd, Wallace Shawn and Charlize Theron. Aug. 10. HAPPY ACCIDENTS -- A sci-fi romantic comedy. Ruby (Marisa Tomei) finds Mr. Right (Vincent D'Onofrio), but he announces that he's from the 25th century. Ruby calls her therapist. Directed by Brad Anderson (''Next Stop Wonderland''). Aug. 10. INNOCENCE -- An Australian music teacher rediscovers his first love, 50 years later. With Charles Tingwell and Julia Blake. Directed by Paul Cox. Aug. 10. JAY AND SILENT BOB STRIKE BACK -- Silent Bob, the comically laconic character that the director Kevin Smith plays in his own films (beginning with ''Clerks''), is finally the star. Jason Mewes plays Jay, a frequent marijuana user. The title characters are upset because someone's making a movie about their lives and they haven't been paid. Aug. 10. A related article is on page 3. OSMOSIS JONES -- Chris Rock plays the voice of a white blood cell, Laurence Fishburne the voice of a virus, and Bill Murray (all of him) the guy in whose body they're racing around as animated characters. The film's live-action sections were directed by the Farrelly brothers, which should guarantee pretty low-level comedy. Aug. 10. THE TURANDOT PROJECT -- Just what it sounds like: a film about the making of a production of Puccini's opera. Zhang Yimou directed the opera, with its man-hating ancient Chinese princess, and Zubin Mehta was musical director. Allan Miller directed the film. The settings are Florence and Beijing. Aug. 10. WAYDOWNTOWN -- A comedy about the great Canadian indoors (offices, malls, food courts, parking garages). Some Calgary co-workers make a bet about who can go longest without actually going outside. With Fabrizio Filippo, Don Mckeller and Gordon Currie. Directed by Gary Burns. Aug. 10. AMERICAN OUTLAWS -- It's a western; it's an action comedy; it's about Jesse James and his gang. With Timothy Dalton, Colin Farrell and Scott Caan (son of James). Les Mayfield (''Flubber,'' ''Encino Man,'' ''2010'') directed. Aug. 17. CAPTAIN CORELLI'S MANDOLIN -- Nicolas Cage and Penélope Cruz in a World War II drama based on Louis de Bernières's novel about a smart and beautiful Greek villager and the Italian soldier, part of Mussolini's occupying army, who wins her heart. Directed by John Madden, whose last film was ''Shakespeare in Love.'' Aug. 17. RAW DEAL: A QUESTION OF CONSENT -- A sure-to-polarize documentary about a University of Florida rape case. Includes the fraternity brothers' sexually graphic home video. Directed by Billy Corben. Aug. 17. ROLLERBALL -- Chris Klein has the James Caan role and John McTiernan directs the remake of Norman Jewison's 1975 film about a sport that makes extreme football and wrestling look like badminton. Jean Reno is the evil team owner, who will do anything for ratings. Set in Kazakhstan in the very near future. Aug. 17. A related article is on page 3. FAMOUS -- From Griffin Dunne, a mock documentary about two would-be stars going through the routine -- casting calls, voice lessons, cosmetic surgery. Spike Lee and Carrie Fisher are among the cameos. Laura Kirk and Nat DeWolf are the stars. Aug. 22. JOHN CARPENTER'S GHOSTS OF MARS -- John Carpenter goes futuristic and extraterrestrial. In 2176, Natasha Henstridge and Ice Cube play cop and criminal on the Red Planet while Martians are taking over the bodies of Earth people who live there. Aug. 24. MAYBE BABY -- A romantic comedy about a couple trying to conceive and writing a movie about trying to conceive. Written and directed by Ben Elton (the British television series ''Blackadder''). Joely Richardson and Hugh Laurie and an impressive supporting cast, including Emma Thompson and Joanna Lumley. Aug. 24. O -- ''Othello'' goes to high school, and it's still a tragedy. Mekhi Phifer plays the title character, who rules the basketball court and loves beautiful Desi (Julia Stiles). But the green-eyed monster has hold of the coach's son (Josh Hartnett). Directed by Tim Blake Nelson. Aug. 24. -- PUNKS -- Four male friends -- one gay, one black, all single -- looking for love. A comedy written and directed by Patrik-Ian Polk. Rockmond Dunbar, Seth Gilliam and Vanessa Williams star. Aug. 24. SERENDIPITY -- John Cusack and Kate Beckinsale in a romance about a couple who meet, love, part and hope to be thrown together again by fate. Ten years later, fate needs a little prodding. Directed by Peter Chelsom, who did ''Town and Country.'' Aug. 24. SOUL SURVIVORS -- After surviving a car accident, a college freshman is visited by something from beyond the grave. With Melissa Sagemiller and Casey Affleck. Directed by Steve Carpenter, whose past work includes ''The Dorm That Dripped Blood.'' Aug. 24. SUMMER CATCH -- Rich girl loves poor baseball player on old Cape Cod. Freddie Prinze Jr. and Jessica Biel star in a romantic comedy directed by Mike Tollin. Aug. 24. TOGETHER -- Members of a Swedish commune finally have to admit the 60's are over. It happens when the commune leader's sister moves in. Lisa Lindgren and Michael Nygvist in a comic drama written and directed by Lukas Moodysson. Aug. 24. VULGAR -- Now Kevin Smith's protégé is making films. Bryan Johnson wrote, directed and stars with Brian O'Halloran in the comic story of a transvestite clown who makes it big. Aug. 24. ALL THAT GLITTERS -- Mariah Carey has appeared in a movie before, but this time she's the star. She plays -- right you are -- a young singer on ''the roller-coaster ride to superstardom.'' Directed by the actor Vondie Curtis-Hall, best known for ''Chicago Hope.'' Aug. 31. KNOCKAROUND GUYS -- Four New York mobsters' sons on their own in Montana. The cast includes John Malkovich, Dennis Hopper, Vin Diesel and Seth Green. A drama written and directed by Brian Koppelman and David Levien. Aug. 31. VENGO -- A Gypsy community, a bloody family feud, revenge and Flamenco music in southern Spain. Written and directed by Tony Gatlif, who did the Gypsy drama ''Gadjo Dilo.'' Antonio Canales plays the proud patriarch mourning his daughter's death. Aug. 31. LES DESTINÉES -- From the Jacques Chardonne novel, an early-20th-century drama with real French star power. Emmanuelle Béart, Isabelle Huppert and Charles Berling star in the story of a minister, his marriage, his new love, two world wars and changing mores. Olivier Assayas directed. August. A MATTER OF TASTE (UNE AFFAIRE DE GOÛT) -- A young waiter is hired as a rich man's personal taster, but the job requires his all. A drama with Bernard Giraudeau and Jean-Pierre Lorit. Directed by Bernard Rapp. August. ON THE EDGE -- A drama about a young man in a mental hospital, the patient he befriends and the suicidal young woman he loves. Cillian Murphy stars; Stephen Rea plays his psychiatrist. Directed by John Carney. August. SADE -- Daniel Auteuil as the Marquis de Sade in a drama set a decade or so before ''Quills'' and in a much nicer prison. Directed by Benoît Jacquot. August.

results.abstract: Rutgers University commencement held; list of honorary degrees awarded (M)

headline.main: Commencement; At Rutgers, Graduation Is a Family Affair

keywords.name: organizations

results.snippet: Among the 10,300 students who graduated from Rutgers University this year were a mother and daughter.    Hindy Alster and her daughter Amy both received bachelor's degrees this afternoon.
results.lead_paragraph: Among the 10,300 students who graduated from Rutgers University this year were a mother and daughter. Hindy Alster and her daughter Amy both received bachelor's degrees this afternoon.

results.snippet: THE runaway success of Mel Brooks' hit musical ''The Producers,'' based on his 1968 film comedy, proves one thing: Broadway's newest formula for success lies in a treasure trove of classic 60's movies waiting to be adapted to the stage. Be on the...

byline.original: By BRUCE KLUGER and DAVID SLAVIN

results.lead_paragraph: THE runaway success of Mel Brooks' hit musical ''The Producers,'' based on his 1968 film comedy, proves one thing: Broadway's newest formula for success lies in a treasure trove of classic 60's movies waiting to be adapted to the stage. Be on the lookout for: Easy Rider!: Move over, Sunshine Boys. Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper reunite on the Great White Way as ageless rebels continuing their 30-year motorcycle trek in search of ''the real America.'' Tony Walton's set is a valentine to the psychedelic 60's, as is the pulsing rock score by the composer David Yazbek (''The Full Monty''), which includes the instant hits ''Bifocal Blues'' and ''We're Just a Coupla Fogeys on Harleys.''

results.abstract: William Zimmer reviews annual competition, Art of the Northeast USA, at Silvermine Art Guild in New Canaan, Conn; photos (M)

headline.main: Prize Winners and a Point of View

results.snippet: THE annual competition ''Art of the Northeast USA'' at the Silvermine Art Guild in New Canaan takes on a different complexion each time out. The 52nd exhibition, now on view, definitely has some color in it, along with the healthy glow that comes...
results.lead_paragraph: THE annual competition ''Art of the Northeast USA'' at the Silvermine Art Guild in New Canaan takes on a different complexion each time out. The 52nd exhibition, now on view, definitely has some color in it, along with the healthy glow that comes from mixing new artists with a lot who are recognizable from past shows. The show was selected by Bill Arning, curator of the MIT List Visual Arts Center in Cambridge, Mass. Recently, and for many years, he ran White Columns, an alternative space in Manhattan. So it's not surprising that the term ''cutting edge'' emerges in his curator's statement. The phrase's meaning has dulled by now, but it can indicate a work of art the likes of which one hasn't quite seen before. There are several that qualify in the 144 works Mr Arning chose from more than 1,000 entries.
